Recent updates View all (27)

October 12

Defender's Quest II: Uematsu Music, Battle Art, Story!

Defender's Quest II: Bitey 
Community Created Artwork for Steam Artwork
By: lars.doucet
Bitey, the armored mobile scavenger base, and captain Javir Deathschild's best friend. (Artwork copyright Level Up Labs)


We've got a treat for you all today, a new Defender's Quest II story post courtesy of our writer James Cavin, a preview of the latest art, and -- the first of several tracks composed by legendary Final Fantasy composer Nobuo Uematsu!

Yes you read that right, several . Our initial deal with Nobuo Uematsu was for just one track, so we were surprised when instead we got nine. Some of these were short little diddies (think of a "Victory fanfare" or "going to sleep at the Inn" tune), but a few were full-length songs. So today you'll get to listen to one of the latter :)

Some quick housekeeping updates:

  • We just released Spanish and Italian translations of the original Defender's Quest.
  • The HD remake of Defender's Quest (see here and here) is nearing completion.
  • The HD remake will be a free update for existing DQI owners
    • It will use existing Steam/GOG/Humble store "slots"
    • Save files will be tested for seamless compatibility
    • You will still have access to the old "legacy" Defender's Quest build if you want
    • DQHD is a native C++ app, so no Flash or AIR in any shape or form on any platform
    • Yes, this means our Linux builds will finally not be a huge pain to install.

Since DQHD is powered by the DQII engine, DQHD's release will mark the end of foundational DQII engine work. After that "all" that's left for us to do will be to finish DQII content. Here's a rough schedule:

  • Next month or two: public demo of DQHD
  • End of 2015 (tentative but looking good): DQHD release on PC (Mac/Windows/Linux)
  • Q1 2016: DQHD release on certain home game consoles (unless there's certification delays)
  • When it's done: DQII

As for the rest of it, you can check out the full information at our blog:

Defender's Quest II: Uemastu Music, Battle Art, Story

13 comments Read more

October 9

Italiano!

Today's 1.1.50 patch includes a full Italian volunteer translation. (Windows/Mac for now, Linux version coming soon).

More updates on the way soon! Stay tuned!

About This Game

Defender's Quest is a Tower-Defense/RPG Hybrid (Think Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense). It focuses on three things: tactical depth, customization, and story. That means no random encounters, no spikey-haired emo kids, no forced time sinks, and no tedious, repetitive battles.

The battle system builds off of tower defense, with individual characters taking the place of towers. Each character levels-up, learns skills, and equips gear individually, allowing the player to customize their battle experience and strategy. The overall game structure is similar to "tactical" RPG's, but with a real-time battle system. Game speed is adjustable, and commands can even be issued while the game is paused.

It also features an engaging, character-driven story written by an actual English major! The story strives to be fast-paced, snappy, and always relevant to gameplay with minimal exposition. Finally, it's got options and accessibility settings out the wazoo, so that you can have the best possible experience!

--------
NOTE: this game is currently locked at 30 FPS. This is mitigated by three factors:

  • You have full control of time, so it doesn't affect reactions.
  • The sprite sheets wouldn't animate any faster at 60 FPS anyway
  • A full HD/60 FPS upgrade is coming soon as a free upgrade .

The crack cocaine of Tower defense/RPG. Excellent writting (especially when you get to new game+ and unlock side missions and the Journal), funny and memorable characters and addicting gameplay that can make hours mysteriously disseapear; while the main quest is resonable in length, a completionist run will probably take you 60+ hours.

21.2 hrs on record
Posted: June 9
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is one of the best tower defense games I've ever played.
It's simply like that, easy to learn and hard to master. The normal gamemode is soo easy even if you only play with the main characters (for the achievement). But after you completed the normal gamemode, you get the harder mode, where you play the story again, but with additional missions for specific characters. There it's going to be impossible to beat the game without using your brain.

Totally worth its money! Gogo buy it, you'll have many good hours ;)

Boss
113 products in account
1 review
Recommended
46.8 hrs on record
Posted: June 23
Surprisingly entertaining. Simple play style, very typical tower defender. The little cutscenes were well written and fun. If you are the type (like me) to enjoy tower defense and other point-and-clicky type games, you'll probably like this. Hell, I definitely got my three dollars worth of entertainment out of this (hail steam sales). The horde-type bonus challenges are neat, and I like the little option to customize palettes for your troops. Makes it easier to tell at a glance who is who, which actually matters since you can level and spend skill points differently making even identical character classes possibly very different in combat. Even paying full price for this would probably be worth it. I can think of PLENTY of expensive triple-A games that I didn't play for almost 50 hours, or get nearly as much pleasure out of playing.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
Aro2220
589 products in account
22 reviews
Recommended
19.3 hrs on record
Posted: August 21
I've played a lot of tower defense. I used to play Warcraft III custom maps where the tower defense genre was cut from. Defender's Quest does a nice job of putting a well developed story with well developed characters into tower defense gameplay without it feeling pasted on.

It keeps it simple. There are only a few basic towers to choose from, but each tower acts like a character in your party and you can equip most of them with weapons and armor (no weapons or armor for a dragon and no armor for the barbarian/main melee guy). The maps are laid out well enough that consideration to where to place your troops does make a big difference.

There is also a nice take on the gameplay by offering 4 difficulty levels. You get rewards for completing the level, but you get bonus rewards for not taking a single point of damage. If you do that, you can get a lot of extra scrap (money) and unique items.

What I'm doing on my second playthrough is going as far as I possibly can while only buying recruits and never any items on the easiest mode. When I hit my first failure, I go back to the very start and try to complete each level on the hardest mode possible. After I fail once, I will go down to an easier mode and so on until I am right back at the easiest mode and therefore, the furthest out I've ever been.

The main game is not that long and there isn't a ton of replayability to this game once you complete it. That is why it is only worth a few bucks...but it's worth a few bucks. I hear they are making a Defender's Quest II and I hope that is at least as good. Even when it is, this is still a pretty fun tower defense and something that feels more refreshing than you might think when you come back to it after a long time.

Nintz
86 products in account
3 reviews
Recommended
24.9 hrs on record
Posted: June 13
This game. This is most likely the biggest surprise in my entire library.

I originally bought this game about two years ago. The Steam Trading Card system had just launched into beta (remember when everyone thought it was going to be huge and a card could be worth $5?) and I had gotten in. Curious to test the system out, I found I at the time did not own any games on the short list of applicable games. I immediately did two things. First, I purchased Half-Life 2 since I had played that game on another account and knew it was good. Second was I started scanning the list for cheap games. This was on a daily deal sale the following day.

I checked it out and saw that is seemed like a pretty generic, if solid, tower defense game. Felt like one of those particularly good flash games on something like Kongregate or Armor Games. Still, for 5 bucks, I figured it was worth a shot.

And I wasn't entirely wrong in my expectations. This does very much feel like a buffed up flash game in a lot of ways. And then I asked myself if that was a bad thing. The gameplay is simple and understandable yet plenty difficult. Creativity is encouraged and different strategies will be required. The graphics weren't amazing, certainly not HD (though a HD update is on its' way at time of writing) but I feel like the art has character to it. This of course is helped by the fact that there actuually is a solid storyline in the game, more than many games I've played. The characters don't have a lot of screentime for development, yet I still feel like they are real.

All in all, this game I found to be a very good surprise. Don't expect a AAA level game, but do expect a game whose simple charm and solid gameplay will leave you satisfied. This game doesn't amaze, but it does the one thing that all games have to do. It's simply entertaining. The devs (who btw are super communicative and dedicated to their games) really did a great job with this one, and I look forward to their future work.

9/10 - Highly Reccomended
